Please provide me with the 500-word write-up on the chanterelle cook-off so I can summarize it for you. 

Once you paste the text, I'll condense it into a concise and informative 150-word summary.

The cook-off drew forty-seven entrants who vanned in from five towns; cast-iron skillets hissed over open birch fires behind the grange. Dishes ran from chanterelle quiche to maple-chanterelle ice cream; judges—our librarian, the game warden, and fire-chief’s wife—scratched notes on 3×5 cards while kids handed out wildflower bouquets. Trophy was a hand-whittled morel atop a cedar plank, claimed by 14-year-old Ellie Tucker for her creamed chanterelle hand pies with thyme. Rain held off until awards, then drummed metal roofs like applause; nobody left early because someone brought cider. Recipe cards swapped themselves on the potluck table; I fished out three for next week’s newsletter. Total haul for the food-bank came to 23 pounds of extra mushrooms and $480 in donations. Folks already ask if we’ll do it again in October, maybe swap the trophy for a giant puffball.

Forty-seven cooks from five towns gathered for a vibrant chanterelle cook-off, filling the air with the aroma of sizzling mushrooms and camaraderie. Dishes ranged from savory quiches to innovative ice cream, judged by local figures while children offered wildflower bouquets. Fourteen-year-old Ellie Tucker won with her creamed chanterelle hand pies, earning a hand-carved morel trophy. Despite a late downpour, the community spirit remained strong, fueled by shared cider and recipe swaps. The event raised 23 pounds of mushrooms and $480 for the food bank, leaving everyone eager for a potential October rematch, perhaps with a giant puffball trophy.
